dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: [Bettina] So Ian, do you know what blockchain is?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Have you ever traded or sold anything?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Actually, I'm selling my computer on eBay right now.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: That's amazing. What made you decide to trade on eBay?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Well, I mean, I've heard of it, and I trust it a lot because they have all of their guarantees, so I know that I'm gonna get money and the person's gonna get what they want.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: So what if I told you that blockchain technology is basically a tool where you can do the exact same thing, but it goes to you and I directly? You wouldn't need an eBay or a brand in between.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: That's cool.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: And there's a lot of those kinds of middlemen in our society today, right? We have a lot of banks.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: We have a lot of companies that sort of help us make sure that our trades happen, but if we could guarantee the same trade using technology as sort of a technological trust, then we wouldn't really need all those middlemen in between.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: So how does it work?

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: It's basically a network of computers that all have the same history of transactions. And so instead of sort of there being one company with one database that holds all the information, the same sort of list is held by all these different people. Like, you could have it on your computer. And then it gets validated by everyone, and basically, that turns into the next part of the list. So it's sort of constantly updating itself.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: So like, how do you make sure that it's secure?

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: So it use cryptography, and that helps it basically encode all of the transactions. So you can't really see exactly what happened, but you can know it happened because it's like a marker.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: So you could kind of like, I don't know, say trade apples, but you would just see like random letters for it?

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Yeah, exactly.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: So you wouldn't be able to track it, I guess?

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: [Bettina] Exactly.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: That's cool.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: So it's kinda this like really big ledger or accounting system for all sorts of things that get traded, but instead of being owned by one company, it's owned by everybody.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: That's cool.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Yeah.
